rules.text: No bigotry or discrimination.  It's on sight.  If you're being a bigot ironically, you will be removed "ironically."

No sectarianism.  If somebody makes a fool of themself, take issue with them and their position.  Do not do the Ben Shapiro / Jesse Waters shtick where you fish for insignificant cranks to discredit broad movements.  Friendly ribbing is OK.

Apply content warnings to any graphic nudity, drug use, gore (including of animals), suicide, sexual violence, hate crimes, slurs, etc. Allow people to opt-in to these discussions instead of forcing them to opt-out.

We do not reject violence on principle.  Our adversaries will not be pacified by rhetoric.  Be mindful about the legal implications of what you say though.  Explicit threats against living people and organizations will be removed.

Be aware of the visibility and context of your posts.  Mastodon is a federated network and different instances have different rules.  If users from this instance regularly violate the rules of other instances, we will be de-federated.
Reactionaries are not welcome.  Liberals will be made fun of until we grow bored.
Don't get arrested.  Don't get me arrested. 😎

records.text: #TheoryMutiny This in itself is a very trivial result of our investigations. Well, to avoid at least the infelicities we have considered:1) what are these statements that have to be true?2) can we say anything exciting about the relation of the performative utterance to them?----- Here Austin downplays whether the reference to (let's call it) truthful circumstances is a small part of what he's uncovered. Sure. I can appreciate where he wants to take this next, though. First, he wants to know what kind of contingent statements support the performative. He doesn't seem as interested in this & frankly neither am I. It seems a little like more definitions. But maybe there's something useful in there. Second, though, he gets a little more passionate, & I do enjoy when people are passionate. He wants to know not just what are contingent statements, but how do they *relate* to performatives? For me, this implies rituals as having settings. Conditions for rituals. A sort of "if X then Y" to human speech, but speech is messy so it's never so elegant.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Now in general this amounted to saying, if you prefer jargon[!], that certain conditions have to be satisfied if the utterance is to be happy--certain things have to be so. And this, it seems clear, commits us to saying that for a certain performative uttrance to be happy, certain statements *have to be true.*----- So what he is saying here, for those of us who like, well, not plain speech exactly, but plainer speech maybe, is that if you're going to say something, you can't just pull it out of your ass. Pulling it out of your ass is, actually, what makes it a shitpost. If I just barge into a conversation randomly with, "Will you marry me?" that's probably inappropriate. The shitpost works because we have a sense of what's appropriate in this quasi-public sphere. We talk about our day, our lives, our interests. We aren't hear to just say random shit. (Or write a wall of text abot theory!) We have to have clear norms & reasons for our speech to satisfy the general things speech is used for. You cannot barge into a converation on the Fediverse with "Will you marry me!" & even have the person say "lol yes" & actually *expect that* to result in marriage. Wrong people, almost certainly, if they are strangers; wrong context, surely, for no one would believe it to be true that it would happen here. The infelictious, in other words, is that which is Simply Not Done. (Yet once again, I would remind you that the campus protests raise the question "Can students affect campus policy in such a way?" How Things are Done isn't immutible; even ways of doing things carve in stone 4000 years ago have obviously changed. These are negotiations. However, Austin isn't describing the negotiations, which I would argue are more visible through anarchist & Marxist theory--only the rituals themselves.)

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So much then for the ways in which performative utterances can be unhappy, with the result that the 'act' concerned is merely purported or professed, &c.----- But then he drops that, because he's not interested in power relations, & I am going to keep us moving along. I'm going for a little more line-by-line reading & a little less commentary, which I do think gets us off track as much as it illustrates, & I hope not to confuse anyone. We have concluded Austin's little list of the impacts of thought, feeling, & intent. We have effectively summed up his thoughts on sincerity in ritual. We have seen that it is only clear in the long-term & in the context of other rituals, too. We need a more or less clear relationship between rituals in order for someone's sincerity to become clear. We cannot know someone's mental state, after all, we can only draw conclusions in inference from their other words & actions. (I think we have many scripts & norms & rituals to test people's intents in just that way.)

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 45 But there is a constant tendency to make this sort of thing clearer, as for example, when we move from 'I forgive' to 'I pardon' or from 'I will' to 'I intend to' or 'I promise.'----- Welcome back! We are still looking at intent in ritual statements, or the way we express social norms. We begin today where we left off yesterday: with the way one ritual sort of "conditions" the ritual speech than can come after. How we put statements in order to make our intentions somewhat clearer. The can of worms Austin's opening up here actually has to do with formality, I think. Clarity, too. "You should put your shoes away," you might say to someone. That's pretty clear, & casual. You would expect the person to respond on the subject of the shoes; you are hoping all responses to follow will be shoe-related. But a casual conversation like this leaves the door open to, "Don't tell me what to do!" or "Ha, what are you, my dad?" So instead you might say, to an acquaintance, "Oh hey, did you mean to put your shoes away? I almost tripped over them," giving more context, an opening to their intentions & acknowledgement of their own internal state of mind &c. But in a more formal context where one has power, one might say, "I advise you to put your shoes away" or if  you are, say, a consultant, "It's advisible to put your shoes away" or "Best practices are to put one's shoes away upon returning home." So it goes, too, in Austin's example. "I forgive you" is a much more casual, feeling-based statement, whereas "I pardon you" is much more formal & (of course) legal. "I will move the car," you tell your mom, but "I promise to move the car," you say to the parking attendant. The more formal, the less wiggle-room you are allowed ... the less wiggle-room you might claim for yourself....

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Or am I just 'not expected' to do so?: or is part of asking-and-taking advice definitely to make such subsequent conduct out of order?----- So, an interesting question. To say "I advise you to do X," does that giving of advice *make* the "well, why did you do that?!" out of order? I think Austin is thinking aloud here. It's pretty clear that, by our words, we give shape to conversation more or less consciously. There are things we might wish would be said, & things we say to stave off other things being said. Keep this in mind when we consider the things words do.

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 44 This does not raise any trouble in principle, however, about the concept of insincerity.----- Welcome back. We are watching Austin open up cans clearly marked "worms" & then lament that there's all these worms everywhere. In general we are looking at how social rituals are seen as void. We're looking at intentions specifically. Last time we touched on that sometimes we say one thing with the intent of then being able to say something else in the future. My example, very quickly touched upon, is our ability to say "We're forming a union!" in order to be able to say, within our lifetime, "Let's hold a General Strike!" Of course, there other, everyday applications too. You can't solicit feedback before providing a service, for example. I might serve you up dinner (banana & peanut butter sandwich, natch) with the intent of later asking you "What did you think of dinner?" All Austin is saying in conclusion of this sub-point is that having an intent to do the next ritual doesn't say much about insincerity, which is *supposed* to be his current focus.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So there are similar possibilities of drawing distinctions in certain ways over what is the requisite intention of performing a *subsequent action* and what is the requisite intention to complete the *present action.*-----(bottom of 43) I think this is a bit of a complicated note to end on for today. Let's say he's gesturing towards complex rituals, & simple ones. It looks like he will show the ways in which one ritual needs a felicitous completion for other rituals to take place. Like if you can't start your day until you've had your coffee, but someone from work calls you at 6 AM. The coffee ritual must come before the work ritual. In some ways a "requisite intention" lines up what will be done later. You can't have a strike before you have a union, for instance, not in any effective or noteworthy way--which a lot of young activists would benefit from reflection on next time they call for a #GeneralStrikeThat's it for doing things with words for today; see you next time.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny This in itself is a very trivial result of our investigations. Well, to avoid at least the infelicities we have considered:1) what are these statements that have to be true?2) can we say anything exciting about the relation of the performative utterance to them?----- Here Austin downplays whether the reference to (let's call it) truthful circumstances is a small part of what he's uncovered. Sure. I can appreciate where he wants to take this next, though. First, he wants to know what kind of contingent statements support the performative. He doesn't seem as interested in this & frankly neither am I. It seems a little like more definitions. But maybe there's something useful in there. Second, though, he gets a little more passionate, & I do enjoy when people are passionate. He wants to know not just what are contingent statements, but how do they *relate* to performatives? For me, this implies rituals as having settings. Conditions for rituals. A sort of "if X then Y" to human speech, but speech is messy so it's never so elegant.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Now in general this amounted to saying, if you prefer jargon[!], that certain conditions have to be satisfied if the utterance is to be happy--certain things have to be so. And this, it seems clear, commits us to saying that for a certain performative uttrance to be happy, certain statements *have to be true.*----- So what he is saying here, for those of us who like, well, not plain speech exactly, but plainer speech maybe, is that if you're going to say something, you can't just pull it out of your ass. Pulling it out of your ass is, actually, what makes it a shitpost. If I just barge into a conversation randomly with, "Will you marry me?" that's probably inappropriate. The shitpost works because we have a sense of what's appropriate in this quasi-public sphere. We talk about our day, our lives, our interests. We aren't hear to just say random shit. (Or write a wall of text abot theory!) We have to have clear norms & reasons for our speech to satisfy the general things speech is used for. You cannot barge into a converation on the Fediverse with "Will you marry me!" & even have the person say "lol yes" & actually *expect that* to result in marriage. Wrong people, almost certainly, if they are strangers; wrong context, surely, for no one would believe it to be true that it would happen here. The infelictious, in other words, is that which is Simply Not Done. (Yet once again, I would remind you that the campus protests raise the question "Can students affect campus policy in such a way?" How Things are Done isn't immutible; even ways of doing things carve in stone 4000 years ago have obviously changed. These are negotiations. However, Austin isn't describing the negotiations, which I would argue are more visible through anarchist & Marxist theory--only the rituals themselves.)

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So much then for the ways in which performative utterances can be unhappy, with the result that the 'act' concerned is merely purported or professed, &c.----- But then he drops that, because he's not interested in power relations, & I am going to keep us moving along. I'm going for a little more line-by-line reading & a little less commentary, which I do think gets us off track as much as it illustrates, & I hope not to confuse anyone. We have concluded Austin's little list of the impacts of thought, feeling, & intent. We have effectively summed up his thoughts on sincerity in ritual. We have seen that it is only clear in the long-term & in the context of other rituals, too. We need a more or less clear relationship between rituals in order for someone's sincerity to become clear. We cannot know someone's mental state, after all, we can only draw conclusions in inference from their other words & actions. (I think we have many scripts & norms & rituals to test people's intents in just that way.)

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 45 But there is a constant tendency to make this sort of thing clearer, as for example, when we move from 'I forgive' to 'I pardon' or from 'I will' to 'I intend to' or 'I promise.'----- Welcome back! We are still looking at intent in ritual statements, or the way we express social norms. We begin today where we left off yesterday: with the way one ritual sort of "conditions" the ritual speech than can come after. How we put statements in order to make our intentions somewhat clearer. The can of worms Austin's opening up here actually has to do with formality, I think. Clarity, too. "You should put your shoes away," you might say to someone. That's pretty clear, & casual. You would expect the person to respond on the subject of the shoes; you are hoping all responses to follow will be shoe-related. But a casual conversation like this leaves the door open to, "Don't tell me what to do!" or "Ha, what are you, my dad?" So instead you might say, to an acquaintance, "Oh hey, did you mean to put your shoes away? I almost tripped over them," giving more context, an opening to their intentions & acknowledgement of their own internal state of mind &c. But in a more formal context where one has power, one might say, "I advise you to put your shoes away" or if  you are, say, a consultant, "It's advisible to put your shoes away" or "Best practices are to put one's shoes away upon returning home." So it goes, too, in Austin's example. "I forgive you" is a much more casual, feeling-based statement, whereas "I pardon you" is much more formal & (of course) legal. "I will move the car," you tell your mom, but "I promise to move the car," you say to the parking attendant. The more formal, the less wiggle-room you are allowed ... the less wiggle-room you might claim for yourself....

And this, it seems clear, commits us to saying that for a certain performative uttrance to be happy, certain statements *have to be true.*----- So what he is saying here, for those of us who like, well, not plain speech exactly, but plainer speech maybe, is that if you're going to say something, you can't just pull it out of your ass. Pulling it out of your ass is, actually, what makes it a shitpost. If I just barge into a conversation randomly with, "Will you marry me?" that's probably inappropriate. The shitpost works because we have a sense of what's appropriate in this quasi-public sphere. We talk about our day, our lives, our interests. We aren't hear to just say random shit. (Or write a wall of text abot theory!) We have to have clear norms & reasons for our speech to satisfy the general things speech is used for. You cannot barge into a converation on the Fediverse with "Will you marry me!" & even have the person say "lol yes" & actually *expect that* to result in marriage. Wrong people, almost certainly, if they are strangers; wrong context, surely, for no one would believe it to be true that it would happen here. The infelictious, in other words, is that which is Simply Not Done. (Yet once again, I would remind you that the campus protests raise the question "Can students affect campus policy in such a way?" How Things are Done isn't immutible; even ways of doing things carve in stone 4000 years ago have obviously changed. These are negotiations. However, Austin isn't describing the negotiations, which I would argue are more visible through anarchist & Marxist theory--only the rituals themselves.)

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 45 But there is a constant tendency to make this sort of thing clearer, as for example, when we move from 'I forgive' to 'I pardon' or from 'I will' to 'I intend to' or 'I promise.'----- Welcome back! We are still looking at intent in ritual statements, or the way we express social norms. We begin today where we left off yesterday: with the way one ritual sort of "conditions" the ritual speech than can come after. How we put statements in order to make our intentions somewhat clearer. The can of worms Austin's opening up here actually has to do with formality, I think. Clarity, too. "You should put your shoes away," you might say to someone. That's pretty clear, & casual. You would expect the person to respond on the subject of the shoes; you are hoping all responses to follow will be shoe-related. But a casual conversation like this leaves the door open to, "Don't tell me what to do!" or "Ha, what are you, my dad?" So instead you might say, to an acquaintance, "Oh hey, did you mean to put your shoes away? I almost tripped over them," giving more context, an opening to their intentions & acknowledgement of their own internal state of mind &c. But in a more formal context where one has power, one might say, "I advise you to put your shoes away" or if  you are, say, a consultant, "It's advisible to put your shoes away" or "Best practices are to put one's shoes away upon returning home." So it goes, too, in Austin's example. "I forgive you" is a much more casual, feeling-based statement, whereas "I pardon you" is much more formal & (of course) legal. "I will move the car," you tell your mom, but "I promise to move the car," you say to the parking attendant. The more formal, the less wiggle-room you are allowed ... the less wiggle-room you might claim for yourself....

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 44 This does not raise any trouble in principle, however, about the concept of insincerity.----- Welcome back. We are watching Austin open up cans clearly marked "worms" & then lament that there's all these worms everywhere. In general we are looking at how social rituals are seen as void. We're looking at intentions specifically. Last time we touched on that sometimes we say one thing with the intent of then being able to say something else in the future. My example, very quickly touched upon, is our ability to say "We're forming a union!" in order to be able to say, within our lifetime, "Let's hold a General Strike!" Of course, there other, everyday applications too. You can't solicit feedback before providing a service, for example. I might serve you up dinner (banana & peanut butter sandwich, natch) with the intent of later asking you "What did you think of dinner?" All Austin is saying in conclusion of this sub-point is that having an intent to do the next ritual doesn't say much about insincerity, which is *supposed* to be his current focus.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So there are similar possibilities of drawing distinctions in certain ways over what is the requisite intention of performing a *subsequent action* and what is the requisite intention to complete the *present action.*-----(bottom of 43) I think this is a bit of a complicated note to end on for today. Let's say he's gesturing towards complex rituals, & simple ones. It looks like he will show the ways in which one ritual needs a felicitous completion for other rituals to take place. Like if you can't start your day until you've had your coffee, but someone from work calls you at 6 AM. The coffee ritual must come before the work ritual. In some ways a "requisite intention" lines up what will be done later. You can't have a strike before you have a union, for instance, not in any effective or noteworthy way--which a lot of young activists would benefit from reflection on next time they call for a #GeneralStrikeThat's it for doing things with words for today; see you next time.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny This in itself is a very trivial result of our investigations. Well, to avoid at least the infelicities we have considered:1) what are these statements that have to be true?2) can we say anything exciting about the relation of the performative utterance to them?----- Here Austin downplays whether the reference to (let's call it) truthful circumstances is a small part of what he's uncovered. Sure. I can appreciate where he wants to take this next, though. First, he wants to know what kind of contingent statements support the performative. He doesn't seem as interested in this & frankly neither am I. It seems a little like more definitions. But maybe there's something useful in there. Second, though, he gets a little more passionate, & I do enjoy when people are passionate. He wants to know not just what are contingent statements, but how do they *relate* to performatives? For me, this implies rituals as having settings. Conditions for rituals. A sort of "if X then Y" to human speech, but speech is messy so it's never so elegant.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So there are similar possibilities of drawing distinctions in certain ways over what is the requisite intention of performing a *subsequent action* and what is the requisite intention to complete the *present action.*-----(bottom of 43) I think this is a bit of a complicated note to end on for today. Let's say he's gesturing towards complex rituals, & simple ones. It looks like he will show the ways in which one ritual needs a felicitous completion for other rituals to take place. Like if you can't start your day until you've had your coffee, but someone from work calls you at 6 AM. The coffee ritual must come before the work ritual. In some ways a "requisite intention" lines up what will be done later. You can't have a strike before you have a union, for instance, not in any effective or noteworthy way--which a lot of young activists would benefit from reflection on next time they call for a #GeneralStrikeThat's it for doing things with words for today; see you next time.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny This in itself is a very trivial result of our investigations. Well, to avoid at least the infelicities we have considered:1) what are these statements that have to be true?2) can we say anything exciting about the relation of the performative utterance to them?----- Here Austin downplays whether the reference to (let's call it) truthful circumstances is a small part of what he's uncovered. Sure. I can appreciate where he wants to take this next, though. First, he wants to know what kind of contingent statements support the performative. He doesn't seem as interested in this & frankly neither am I. It seems a little like more definitions. But maybe there's something useful in there. Second, though, he gets a little more passionate, & I do enjoy when people are passionate. He wants to know not just what are contingent statements, but how do they *relate* to performatives? For me, this implies rituals as having settings. Conditions for rituals. A sort of "if X then Y" to human speech, but speech is messy so it's never so elegant.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Now in general this amounted to saying, if you prefer jargon[!], that certain conditions have to be satisfied if the utterance is to be happy--certain things have to be so. And this, it seems clear, commits us to saying that for a certain performative uttrance to be happy, certain statements *have to be true.*----- So what he is saying here, for those of us who like, well, not plain speech exactly, but plainer speech maybe, is that if you're going to say something, you can't just pull it out of your ass. Pulling it out of your ass is, actually, what makes it a shitpost. If I just barge into a conversation randomly with, "Will you marry me?" that's probably inappropriate. The shitpost works because we have a sense of what's appropriate in this quasi-public sphere. We talk about our day, our lives, our interests. We aren't hear to just say random shit. (Or write a wall of text abot theory!) We have to have clear norms & reasons for our speech to satisfy the general things speech is used for. You cannot barge into a converation on the Fediverse with "Will you marry me!" & even have the person say "lol yes" & actually *expect that* to result in marriage. Wrong people, almost certainly, if they are strangers; wrong context, surely, for no one would believe it to be true that it would happen here. The infelictious, in other words, is that which is Simply Not Done. (Yet once again, I would remind you that the campus protests raise the question "Can students affect campus policy in such a way?" How Things are Done isn't immutible; even ways of doing things carve in stone 4000 years ago have obviously changed. These are negotiations. However, Austin isn't describing the negotiations, which I would argue are more visible through anarchist & Marxist theory--only the rituals themselves.)

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So much then for the ways in which performative utterances can be unhappy, with the result that the 'act' concerned is merely purported or professed, &c.----- But then he drops that, because he's not interested in power relations, & I am going to keep us moving along. I'm going for a little more line-by-line reading & a little less commentary, which I do think gets us off track as much as it illustrates, & I hope not to confuse anyone. We have concluded Austin's little list of the impacts of thought, feeling, & intent. We have effectively summed up his thoughts on sincerity in ritual. We have seen that it is only clear in the long-term & in the context of other rituals, too. We need a more or less clear relationship between rituals in order for someone's sincerity to become clear. We cannot know someone's mental state, after all, we can only draw conclusions in inference from their other words & actions. (I think we have many scripts & norms & rituals to test people's intents in just that way.)

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 45 But there is a constant tendency to make this sort of thing clearer, as for example, when we move from 'I forgive' to 'I pardon' or from 'I will' to 'I intend to' or 'I promise.'----- Welcome back! We are still looking at intent in ritual statements, or the way we express social norms. We begin today where we left off yesterday: with the way one ritual sort of "conditions" the ritual speech than can come after. How we put statements in order to make our intentions somewhat clearer. The can of worms Austin's opening up here actually has to do with formality, I think. Clarity, too. "You should put your shoes away," you might say to someone. That's pretty clear, & casual. You would expect the person to respond on the subject of the shoes; you are hoping all responses to follow will be shoe-related. But a casual conversation like this leaves the door open to, "Don't tell me what to do!" or "Ha, what are you, my dad?" So instead you might say, to an acquaintance, "Oh hey, did you mean to put your shoes away? I almost tripped over them," giving more context, an opening to their intentions & acknowledgement of their own internal state of mind &c. But in a more formal context where one has power, one might say, "I advise you to put your shoes away" or if  you are, say, a consultant, "It's advisible to put your shoes away" or "Best practices are to put one's shoes away upon returning home." So it goes, too, in Austin's example. "I forgive you" is a much more casual, feeling-based statement, whereas "I pardon you" is much more formal & (of course) legal. "I will move the car," you tell your mom, but "I promise to move the car," you say to the parking attendant. The more formal, the less wiggle-room you are allowed ... the less wiggle-room you might claim for yourself....

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Or am I just 'not expected' to do so?: or is part of asking-and-taking advice definitely to make such subsequent conduct out of order?----- So, an interesting question. To say "I advise you to do X," does that giving of advice *make* the "well, why did you do that?!" out of order? I think Austin is thinking aloud here. It's pretty clear that, by our words, we give shape to conversation more or less consciously. There are things we might wish would be said, & things we say to stave off other things being said. Keep this in mind when we consider the things words do.

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 44 This does not raise any trouble in principle, however, about the concept of insincerity.----- Welcome back. We are watching Austin open up cans clearly marked "worms" & then lament that there's all these worms everywhere. In general we are looking at how social rituals are seen as void. We're looking at intentions specifically. Last time we touched on that sometimes we say one thing with the intent of then being able to say something else in the future. My example, very quickly touched upon, is our ability to say "We're forming a union!" in order to be able to say, within our lifetime, "Let's hold a General Strike!" Of course, there other, everyday applications too. You can't solicit feedback before providing a service, for example. I might serve you up dinner (banana & peanut butter sandwich, natch) with the intent of later asking you "What did you think of dinner?" All Austin is saying in conclusion of this sub-point is that having an intent to do the next ritual doesn't say much about insincerity, which is *supposed* to be his current focus.

But in a more formal context where one has power, one might say, "I advise you to put your shoes away" or if  you are, say, a consultant, "It's advisible to put your shoes away" or "Best practices are to put one's shoes away upon returning home." So it goes, too, in Austin's example. "I forgive you" is a much more casual, feeling-based statement, whereas "I pardon you" is much more formal & (of course) legal. "I will move the car," you tell your mom, but "I promise to move the car," you say to the parking attendant. The more formal, the less wiggle-room you are allowed ... the less wiggle-room you might claim for yourself....

records.text: #TheoryMutiny Or am I just 'not expected' to do so?: or is part of asking-and-taking advice definitely to make such subsequent conduct out of order?----- So, an interesting question. To say "I advise you to do X," does that giving of advice *make* the "well, why did you do that?!" out of order? I think Austin is thinking aloud here. It's pretty clear that, by our words, we give shape to conversation more or less consciously. There are things we might wish would be said, & things we say to stave off other things being said. Keep this in mind when we consider the things words do.

records.text: How to Do Things with Words by J. L. Austin Chapter IV: Infelicities: AbusesPage 44 This does not raise any trouble in principle, however, about the concept of insincerity.----- Welcome back. We are watching Austin open up cans clearly marked "worms" & then lament that there's all these worms everywhere. In general we are looking at how social rituals are seen as void. We're looking at intentions specifically. Last time we touched on that sometimes we say one thing with the intent of then being able to say something else in the future. My example, very quickly touched upon, is our ability to say "We're forming a union!" in order to be able to say, within our lifetime, "Let's hold a General Strike!" Of course, there other, everyday applications too. You can't solicit feedback before providing a service, for example. I might serve you up dinner (banana & peanut butter sandwich, natch) with the intent of later asking you "What did you think of dinner?" All Austin is saying in conclusion of this sub-point is that having an intent to do the next ritual doesn't say much about insincerity, which is *supposed* to be his current focus.

records.text: #TheoryMutiny So there are similar possibilities of drawing distinctions in certain ways over what is the requisite intention of performing a *subsequent action* and what is the requisite intention to complete the *present action.*-----(bottom of 43) I think this is a bit of a complicated note to end on for today. Let's say he's gesturing towards complex rituals, & simple ones. It looks like he will show the ways in which one ritual needs a felicitous completion for other rituals to take place. Like if you can't start your day until you've had your coffee, but someone from work calls you at 6 AM. The coffee ritual must come before the work ritual. In some ways a "requisite intention" lines up what will be done later. You can't have a strike before you have a union, for instance, not in any effective or noteworthy way--which a lot of young activists would benefit from reflection on next time they call for a #GeneralStrikeThat's it for doing things with words for today; see you next time.
